output.conclusion: This course provides a comprehensive understanding of fluid mechanics at an advanced level, equipping students with the knowledge and skills to analyze and solve complex fluid flow problems.
output.introduction: Welcome to Advanced Fluid Mechanics! This course delves into the fundamental principles governing fluid behavior, building upon introductory concepts to explore more complex phenomena and applications. We will cover topics ranging from advanced conservation laws to turbulence modeling and computational fluid dynamics.

chapters.description: Introduction to tensor notation and its application to fluid mechanics. Deformation rate tensor, vorticity tensor, and their physical interpretations.
A detailed look at the Reynolds Transport Theorem and its applications to deriving conservation equations for mass, momentum, and energy in integral form.
Discussion of Newtonian and non-Newtonian fluid models. Derivation and application of constitutive equations for various fluid types.
Derivation of the Navier-Stokes equations from first principles. Discussion of the assumptions and limitations of the equations.
Analysis of classic exact solutions, including Couette flow, Poiseuille flow, and Stokes' first and second problems.
Study of vorticity transport equation. Vortex stretching, tilting, and diffusion. Kelvin's circulation theorem.
Introduction to boundary layer approximations. Derivation of the Prandtl boundary layer equations.
Blasius solution for flow over a flat plate. Falkner-Skan solutions for wedge flows.
Analysis of heat transfer in boundary layers. Derivation of the energy equation and its solutions.
Characteristics of turbulent flows. Reynolds decomposition and Reynolds-averaged Navier-Stokes (RANS) equations.
Overview of different turbulence models, including k-epsilon, k-omega, and Reynolds stress models.
Analysis of turbulent boundary layers. Law of the wall and velocity profiles.
Overview of computational fluid dynamics methods. Finite difference, finite volume, and finite element methods.
Discussion of different discretization schemes for convection and diffusion terms. Stability and accuracy considerations.
Examples of CFD applications in various engineering fields, such as aerodynamics, heat transfer, and multiphase flows.
